comments.body: Are both of you ok with being added as maintainers of `instaseis` at [conda-forge](http://conda-forge.github.io/), @martinvandriel and @sstaehler?
Sure. Good to see this stuff beeing added to conda...
Try adding `- ulimit -n <X>` and pick some integer for `<X>` that is larger than `256`. If Travis CI still fails, bump it. Appears that this will automatically be reset once testing ends.

I was a bit cautious about this because it might just set a very low ulimit for somebodies machine if they choose to run this which might immediately crash the machine. I think the current solution is safe enough.

Is there a way to have selectors in the `meta.yaml` file check for the existence of environment variables? That would make it straightforward to check if something runs in travis or not.

This is just the Mac OS default. For instance on CentOS 6 I find it is `1048576`. IMHO Apple is being way too cautious.

Though I understand the desire not to muck with these system defaults. The place to solve this will be in the test suite itself.

Personally I think you are ok making this sort of limit change for now. Maybe you will want to experiment to more carefully determine how large it can be.

> Is there a way to have selectors in the `meta.yaml` file check for the existence of environment variables? That would make it straightforward to check if something runs in travis or not.

Not with selectors, but you could use [environment variables](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/osx-ci-environment/#Environment-variables).

Alright - this seemed to have worked. I pushed one more commit that results in a lot less tests being run on OSX - the test runner takes too long otherwise...its only a couple of percent of test coverage that gets added with these generated tests and I'm confident everything still works well enough on OSX.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +38,42 @@  imports:
    - instaseis
  commands:
    # Travis' OSX tests require more open files.
    - if [[ $TRAVIS == true ]]; then ulimit -n 2048 ; fi  # [osx]
